articles.headline: Romney Works to Put Skeptics’ Doubts to Rest
articles.snippet: Many conservative Christians are concerned about Mitt Romney’s religion and his recent shift on abortion rights.
articles.abstract: Many conservative Christians are concerned about Mitt Romney’s religion and his recent shift on abortion rights.
articles.lead_paragraph: AMES, Iowa, May 10 — Bart Pals, a county chairman for Mitt Romney’s presidential campaign, had been given talking points to use when he introduced the former Massachusetts governor at an event in northern Iowa on Wednesday.

articles.headline: JetBlue’s Leader Is Giving Up Chief Executive Title
articles.snippet: After months of being beaten up over a service meltdown at the company he founded, David G. Neeleman reluctantly agreed to step aside.
articles.abstract: After months of being beaten up over a service meltdown at the company he founded, David G. Neeleman reluctantly agreed to step aside.
articles.lead_paragraph: Everyone takes things personally, but David G. Neeleman is that rare corporate executive who admits to those feelings.

articles.headline: Puffing Away That PG Rating
articles.snippet: The Motion Picture Association of America said portrayals of smoking would be considered alongside sex and violence in assessing the suitability of movies for young viewers.
articles.abstract: The Motion Picture Association of America said portrayals of smoking would be considered alongside sex and violence in assessing the suitability of movies for young viewers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, May 10 — WARNING: Smoking may be hazardous to your movie rating.

articles.headline: $350 Liquor? Just Spreading the Wealth
articles.snippet: Private enterprise is stepping in as the government no longer fills a role it once did: income redistribution.
articles.abstract: Private enterprise is stepping in as the government no longer fills a role it once did: income redistribution.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steve Leuthold, a money manager out of Minneapolis, told his clients last month that he was appalled by something he had read in The New York Times.

articles.headline: Narcotic Maker Guilty of Deceit Over Marketing
articles.snippet: The company that makes the painkiller OxyContin pleaded guilty to criminal charges that the firm had misled doctors and patients.
articles.abstract: The company that makes the painkiller OxyContin pleaded guilty to criminal charges that the firm had misled doctors and patients.
articles.lead_paragraph: ABINGDON, Va., May 10 — The company that makes the painkiller OxyContin and three of its current and former executives pleaded guilty Thursday in federal court here to criminal charges that it had misled doctors and patients when it claimed the drug was less likely to be abused than traditional narcotics.

articles.headline: Pressed by Police, Even Innocent Confess in Japan
articles.snippet: Recent criminal cases have shown just how far the Japanese authorities will go in securing confessions.
articles.abstract: Recent criminal cases have shown just how far the Japanese authorities will go in securing confessions.
articles.lead_paragraph: SHIBUSHI, Japan — The suspects in a vote-buying case in this small town in western Japan were subjected to repeated interrogations and, in several instances, months of pretrial detention. The police ordered one woman to shout her confession out a window and forced one man to stomp on the names of his loved ones.

articles.headline: Highway Debris, Long an Eyesore, Grows as Hazard
articles.snippet: California is beginning to address the issue of deaths caused by accidents involving objects on highways.
articles.abstract: California is beginning to address the issue of deaths caused by accidents involving objects on highways.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9 — It was just another California rush hour. On eastbound Interstate 580 near Pleasanton recently, a rocking chair brought traffic to a near-standstill, while on southbound I-680 near Walnut Creek, a trampoline blocked two left lanes, wreaking havoc on the morning commute. Bagged loaves of sourdough bread blocked U.S. 101, near Petaluma. The highway patrol had to be dispatched.

articles.headline: Bush and Democrats in Accord on Trade Deals
articles.snippet: The agreement clears the way for early passage of some pending trade accords and improves prospects for others.
articles.abstract: The agreement clears the way for early passage of some pending trade accords and improves prospects for others.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, May 10 — The Bush administration reached agreement on Thursday with the House speaker, Nancy Pelosi, and other Democrats to attach environmental and worker protections in several pending trade accords, clearing the way for early passage of some pacts and improving prospects for others.

articles.headline: Panel to Look at Conflicts in Consulting
articles.snippet: Congress is looking into potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do lucrative work for companies whose pay they help devise.
articles.abstract: Congress is looking into potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do lucrative work for companies whose pay they help devise.
articles.lead_paragraph: Members of Congress are looking into the potential conflicts among executive compensation consulting firms that do other lucrative work for the companies whose pay they help devise.

articles.headline: Retail Sales Fell Sharply Last Month
articles.snippet: Sales were dismal, suggesting that rising gas prices and the flagging housing market are starting to weigh on consumers.
articles.abstract: Sales were dismal, suggesting that rising gas prices and the flagging housing market are starting to weigh on consumers.
articles.lead_paragraph: From department stores to discount chains, sales were dismal last month, suggesting that rising gas prices and the flagging housing market are starting to weigh on American consumers.
articles.byline: By Jeremy W. Peters and Michael Barbaro
